To run this script: 1. Download HINTS 5 datasets from <https://hints.cancer.gov/view-questions-topics/all-hints-questions.aspx> to your data folder. Download all cycles of the data. 2. In the data folder, unzip each dataset. 3. Change the location parameter for the `get_hints5` call in the block below to point to your data folder. 4. Run this script.

```{r message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
Sys.setenv(R_CONFIG_ACTIVE = Sys.info()["nodename"])

library(dplyr)
library(lavaan)
library(mediation)
source("HINTS_preprocessing.R")
source("orfcs_utilities.R")
source("gen_utilities.R")
hints5 <-get_hints5(location=config::get("hints_protected_data_folderpath"))
hints5$HINTSIsRural[grepl("Not coded",hints5$PR_RUCA_2010)]<-NA
hints5$HINTSIsRural_i[grepl("Not coded",hints5$PR_RUCA_2010)]<-NA

boot_times<-10000

zscore <- function(x){
    return((x-mean(x,na.rm=TRUE))/sd(x,na.rm=TRUE))
}
```

```{r}
library(stringi)
# [1] "Fruit_vegetables_z~HINTSIsRural_i+Age_c+I(Age_c^2)+RacePP+Gender3C+filename"
# [1] "MedConditions_HighBP_i~Fruit_vegetables_z+HINTSIsRural_i+Age_c+I(Age_c^2)+RacePP+Gender3C+filename"
# IncomeRanges_r

#need to do prepare variables so lavaan can process them
hints5_pp <- hints5
#add quadratic
hints5_pp$Age_c_pow2 <- hints5_pp$Age_c^2


#one-hot some variables
factor_to_clean_string <- function(data, col_to_stringify){
  data[[col_to_stringify]] <- as.character(data[[col_to_stringify]])
  data[[col_to_stringify]] <- (
    str_replace_all(data[[col_to_stringify]],"\\s","_") %>% 
      str_replace_all("\\W","")
  )#table(hints5_pp[[col_to_stringify]])
  return(data)
}

hints5_pp<-factor_to_clean_string(hints5_pp,"RacePP2")
hints5_pp$RacePP2<-factor(hints5_pp$RacePP2)
hints5_pp <- mltools::one_hot(hints5_pp,"RacePP2",dropCols = FALSE)
print(paste0(colnames(hints5_pp)[grepl("RacePP2_",colnames(hints5_pp))],collapse=" + "))

hints5_pp<-factor_to_clean_string(hints5_pp,"Hisp_Cat2")
hints5_pp$Hisp_Cat2<-factor(hints5_pp$Hisp_Cat2,levels=names(sort(table(hints5_pp$Hisp_Cat2),decreasing = TRUE)))
hints5_pp <- mltools::one_hot(hints5_pp,"Hisp_Cat2",dropCols = FALSE)
print(paste0(colnames(hints5_pp)[grepl("Hisp_Cat2_",colnames(hints5_pp))],collapse=" + "))

hints5_pp<-factor_to_clean_string(hints5_pp,"Gender3C")
hints5_pp$Gender3C<-factor(hints5_pp$Gender3C)
hints5_pp <- mltools::one_hot(hints5_pp,"Gender3C",dropCols = FALSE)
print(paste0(colnames(hints5_pp)[grepl("Gender3C_",colnames(hints5_pp))],collapse=" + "))
```

# HINTS dataset: two mediators

This follows Hayes PROCESS Model 6 with two mediators but we are doing it here in Lavaan.

Variables are:

-   Treatment: Rurality
-   Two Mediators: household income, and fruit and vegetable consumption, in that order.
-   Outcome: Physical and health measures. Altogether, we'll repeat the mediation several times, with the following outcomes variables: BMI, self-rated health, aggregated cardiometabolic health, and high blood pressure. (and cancer??)

This model below is adapted from <https://towardsdatascience.com/doing-and-reporting-a-serial-mediation-model-with-two-mediators-in-r-with-lavaan-739ed3155814>

I think they've left some things out. I need to do a bit more research to work out how to properly implement this, probably including a basic crash course in SEM.

For the basic HINTs lms, see `HINTS_health_outcomes.Rmd`.

```{r}
#TREAT=HINTSIsRural_i
#m1=IncomeRanges_r
#m2=Fruit_vegetables_z
#OUTCOME=MedConditions_HighBP_i


#NEXT TO DO: DEAL WITH CATEGORICAL DATA. GUIDE HERE: https://lavaan.ugent.be/tutorial/cat.html
hints_model_template=
"
  #Regressions
  IncomeRanges_r ~ ab*HINTSIsRural_i + Age_c + Age_c_pow2 + Gender3C_Male + Gender3C_MissingOrMultiple + RacePP2_American_Indian_or_Alaska_Native + RacePP2_Asian_Indian + RacePP2_Black + RacePP2_Chinese + RacePP2_Filipino + RacePP2_Japanese + RacePP2_Korean + RacePP2_Missing_Data + RacePP2_Multiple_races_selected + RacePP2_Other_Asian + RacePP2_Pacific_Islander + RacePP2_Vietnamese + Hisp_Cat2_Unknown + Hisp_Cat2_Mexican + Hisp_Cat2_Other_Hispanic + Hisp_Cat2_Puerto_Rican + Hisp_Cat2_Multiple_Hispanic_ethnicities_selected + Hisp_Cat2_Cuban
  
  Fruit_vegetables_z ~ bc*IncomeRanges_r + ac*HINTSIsRural_i + Age_c + Age_c_pow2 + Gender3C_Male + Gender3C_MissingOrMultiple + RacePP2_American_Indian_or_Alaska_Native + RacePP2_Asian_Indian + RacePP2_Black + RacePP2_Chinese + RacePP2_Filipino + RacePP2_Japanese + RacePP2_Korean + RacePP2_Missing_Data + RacePP2_Multiple_races_selected + RacePP2_Other_Asian + RacePP2_Pacific_Islander + RacePP2_Vietnamese + Hisp_Cat2_Unknown + Hisp_Cat2_Mexican + Hisp_Cat2_Other_Hispanic + Hisp_Cat2_Puerto_Rican + Hisp_Cat2_Multiple_Hispanic_ethnicities_selected + Hisp_Cat2_Cuban
  
  (OUTCOMEVAR) ~ cd*Fruit_vegetables_z + bd*IncomeRanges_r + ad*HINTSIsRural_i + Age_c + Age_c_pow2 + Gender3C_Male + Gender3C_MissingOrMultiple + RacePP2_American_Indian_or_Alaska_Native + RacePP2_Asian_Indian + RacePP2_Black + RacePP2_Chinese + RacePP2_Filipino + RacePP2_Japanese + RacePP2_Korean + RacePP2_Missing_Data + RacePP2_Multiple_races_selected + RacePP2_Other_Asian + RacePP2_Pacific_Islander + RacePP2_Vietnamese + Hisp_Cat2_Unknown + Hisp_Cat2_Mexican + Hisp_Cat2_Other_Hispanic + Hisp_Cat2_Puerto_Rican + Hisp_Cat2_Multiple_Hispanic_ethnicities_selected + Hisp_Cat2_Cuban
  
  
  #Defined Parameters:
  indirect_effect := ab*bc*cd
  effect_via_inc_only :=ab*bd
  effect_via_fruit_vege_only :=ac*cd
  direct_effect := ad
"

# - Outcome: Physical and health measures. Altogether, we'll repeat the mediation several times, with the following outcomes variables: BMI, self-rated health, aggregated cardiometabolic health, and high blood pressure.

outcome_measures <- c(
  "BMI",
  "GeneralHealth_i",
  "MedConditionsAggregate",
  "MedConditions_HighBP_i",
  "EverHadCancer_i"#no cancer for now, doesn't seem very important.
  )




```

```{r}



hints_fits_by_outcome<- list()

for (outcome_var in outcome_measures){
  set.seed(05711846)
  hints_model_w_outcome <- str_replace_all(hints_model_template,"\\(OUTCOMEVAR\\)",outcome_var)
  cat(paste0("MEDIATION MODEL FOR OUTCOME: ",outcome_var))
  cat(hints_model_w_outcome)
  fit=sem(
    hints_model_w_outcome,
    hints5_pp,
    se = "bootstrap",
    bootstrap=boot_times,
    likelihood = "wishart")
  
  hints_fits_by_outcome[[outcome_var]]<-fit
  print(summary(fit,ci=TRUE))
  cat("-----\n\n\n")
}
```

```{r}
#NEXT TO DO: DEAL WITH CATEGORICAL DATA. GUIDE HERE: https://lavaan.ugent.be/tutorial/cat.html
hints_model_template_int=
"
  #Regressions
  IncomeRanges_r ~ ab*HINTSIsRural_i + Age_c + Age_c_pow2 + Gender3C_Male + Gender3C_MissingOrMultiple + RacePP2_American_Indian_or_Alaska_Native + RacePP2_Asian_Indian + RacePP2_Black + RacePP2_Chinese + RacePP2_Filipino + RacePP2_Japanese + RacePP2_Korean + RacePP2_Missing_Data + RacePP2_Multiple_races_selected + RacePP2_Other_Asian + RacePP2_Pacific_Islander + RacePP2_Vietnamese + Hisp_Cat2_Unknown + Hisp_Cat2_Mexican + Hisp_Cat2_Other_Hispanic + Hisp_Cat2_Puerto_Rican + Hisp_Cat2_Multiple_Hispanic_ethnicities_selected + Hisp_Cat2_Cuban
  
  Fruit_vegetables_z ~ bc*IncomeRanges_r + ac*HINTSIsRural_i + bc_g*IncomeRanges_r:HINTSIsRural_i + Age_c + Age_c_pow2 + Gender3C_Male + Gender3C_MissingOrMultiple + RacePP2_American_Indian_or_Alaska_Native + RacePP2_Asian_Indian + RacePP2_Black + RacePP2_Chinese + RacePP2_Filipino + RacePP2_Japanese + RacePP2_Korean + RacePP2_Missing_Data + RacePP2_Multiple_races_selected + RacePP2_Other_Asian + RacePP2_Pacific_Islander + RacePP2_Vietnamese + Hisp_Cat2_Unknown + Hisp_Cat2_Mexican + Hisp_Cat2_Other_Hispanic + Hisp_Cat2_Puerto_Rican + Hisp_Cat2_Multiple_Hispanic_ethnicities_selected + Hisp_Cat2_Cuban
  
  (OUTCOMEVAR) ~ cd*Fruit_vegetables_z + bd*IncomeRanges_r + ad*HINTSIsRural_i + cd_g*Fruit_vegetables_z:HINTSIsRural_i + Age_c + Age_c_pow2 + Gender3C_Male + Gender3C_MissingOrMultiple + RacePP2_American_Indian_or_Alaska_Native + RacePP2_Asian_Indian + RacePP2_Black + RacePP2_Chinese + RacePP2_Filipino + RacePP2_Japanese + RacePP2_Korean + RacePP2_Missing_Data + RacePP2_Multiple_races_selected + RacePP2_Other_Asian + RacePP2_Pacific_Islander + RacePP2_Vietnamese + Hisp_Cat2_Unknown + Hisp_Cat2_Mexican + Hisp_Cat2_Other_Hispanic + Hisp_Cat2_Puerto_Rican + Hisp_Cat2_Multiple_Hispanic_ethnicities_selected + Hisp_Cat2_Cuban
  
  
  #Defined Parameters:
  indirect_effect_ctrl := ab*bc*cd
  indirect_effect_treat := ab*(bc+bc_g)*(cd+cd_g)
  indirect_effect_avg := (ab*bc*cd + ab*(bc+bc_g)*(cd+cd_g))/2
  indirect_effect_diff := ab*bc*cd - ab*(bc+bc_g)*(cd+cd_g)
  effect_via_inc_only :=ab*bd
  effect_via_fruit_vege_only :=ac*cd
  direct_effect := ad
"

# - Outcome: Physical and health measures. Altogether, we'll repeat the mediation several times, with the following outcomes variables: BMI, self-rated health, aggregated cardiometabolic health, and high blood pressure.

outcome_measures <- c(
  "BMI",
  "GeneralHealth_i",
  "MedConditionsAggregate", #would benefit from being modelled as a poisson or something.x`
  "MedConditions_HighBP_i",
  "EverHadCancer_i"#no cancer for now, doesn't seem very important.
  )
```

## three mediators

For comparison with HINTS, we'll first repeat the HINTS dataset two-mediator model as described above, but using three mediators.

Then, we'll proceed with our main Oregon dataset analysis.

This follows Hayes PROCESS Model 6 with THREE mediators but we are doing it here in Lavaan.

Variables are:

-   Treatment: Rurality
-   Two Mediators: household income, MESA healthy food availability, and fruit and vegetable consumption, in that order.
-   Outcome: Physical and health measures. Altogether, we'll repeat the mediation several times, with the following outcomes variables: BMI, self-rated health, aggregated cardiometabolic health, and high blood pressure.

```{r}
#TREAT=HINTSIsRural_i
#m1=IncomeRanges_r
#m2=Fruit_vegetables_z
#OUTCOME=MedConditions_HighBP_i


# mb <- lm(MESA_healthyfoodavailability_z~RuralZIP_i+Gender3C+DEMO_Age_c+RaceC2+PSS_z,data_to_measure)
# mc <- lm(BMI~RuralZIP_i+Gender3C+DEMO_Age_c+RaceC2+MESA_healthyfoodavailability_z+PSS_z,data_to_measure)

# [1] "RaceC2_Asian + RaceC2_HawaiianOtherPacificIslander + RaceC2_HispanicAnyRace + RaceC2_OtherRaceRaceNotReported + RaceC2_WhiteOnly"
# [1] "Gender3C_Female + Gender3C_Male + Gender3C_Other"

#NEXT TO DO: DEAL WITH CATEGORICAL DATA. GUIDE HERE: https://lavaan.ugent.be/tutorial/cat.html
oregon_model_template=
"
```

# Hybrid: three mediators

This follows Hayes PROCESS Model 6 with THREE mediators. We need to somehow manually combine the two datasets by multiplying effects. Need to follow bootstrap analysis, which means we need to extract raw bootstrap results and combine them. I'm not sure it's feasible, but it would be quite valuable to do.

Variables are:

-   Treatment: Rurality
-   Two Mediators: household income, MESA healthy food availability, and fruit and vegetable consumption, in that order.
-   Outcome: Physical and health measures. Altogether, we'll repeat the mediation several times, with the following outcomes variables: BMI, self-rated health, aggregated cardiometabolic health, and high blood pressure.

## Hybrid Analysis run

```{r}
get_fit_PE<-function(fit_to_read){
  sink("temp_out.txt")
  fit_pe<-summary(fit_to_read,ci=TRUE)$pe
  sink(NULL)
  return(fit_pe)
}

lavaan_results_list <- list()
for (hints_fit_label in names(hints_fits_by_outcome)){
  hints_fit<-hints_fits_by_outcome[[hints_fit_label]]
  lavaan_summarized_results <- get_fit_PE(hints_fit) %>% filter(label!="")
  lavaan_summarized_results[["outcome"]]<-hints_fit_label
  lavaan_results_list<-append(lavaan_results_list,list(lavaan_summarized_results))
}
lavaan_results_df <- do.call(rbind,lavaan_results_list)
```


```{r, warning=FALSE}



orfcs_boot<-extract_and_label_bootstrap_results(orfcs_fit)
colnames(orfcs_boot)<-
  paste0("orfcs_",colnames(orfcs_boot))

#raw_data_list<-list()

hybrid_effect_list <-list()
for (effect_name in names(hints_fits_by_outcome)){
  cat(paste0("HYBRID INDIRECT EFFECT FOR: ",effect_name,"\n\n"))
  hints_boot <-extract_and_label_bootstrap_results(hints_fits_by_outcome[[effect_name]])
  # sink("temp_diversion.txt")
  # lavaan_computed_indirect_effect <- (
  #   summary(hints_fits_by_outcome[[effect_name]])$PE %>% filter(label=="indirect_effect")
  # )
  # sink(NULL)
  colnames(hints_boot)<-
    paste0("hints_",colnames(hints_boot))
  
  
  row_count <- min(nrow(orfcs_boot),nrow(hints_boot))
  combined_boot_results <- data.frame(cbind(orfcs_boot[1:row_count,],hints_boot[1:row_count,]))
  
  #raw_data_list[[effect_name]]<-combined_boot_results
  
  # cat("HINTS lavaan pre-computed indirect effect:\n")
  # cat(paste(names(lavaan_computed_indirect_effect),collapse="\t"))
  # cat(paste(lavaan_computed_indirect_effect,collapse="\t"))
  # 
  # cat("\n")

  cat("HINTS indirect effect:\n ")  
  HINTS_indirect_effect <- apply(combined_boot_results %>% dplyr::select(hints_ab, hints_bc, hints_cd),1,prod)
  summarize_calculated_effect(HINTS_indirect_effect)
  
  cat("HINTS direct effect:\n ")  
  HINTS_direct_effect <- combined_boot_results$hints_ad
  hie_result<- summarize_calculated_effect(HINTS_direct_effect)
  hybrid_effect_set<-list("indirect_effect"=hie_result)
  
  cat("Hybrid indirect effect:\n ")
  hybrid_main_indirect_effect <- apply(combined_boot_results %>% dplyr::select(hints_ab, orfcs_bc,orfcs_cd, hints_cd),1,prod)
  hie_result <- summarize_calculated_effect(hybrid_main_indirect_effect)
  hybrid_effect_set<-list("indirect_effect"=hie_result)
  
  cat("Hybrid effect via food availability and consumption:\n ")
  hybrid_indirect_effect1 <- apply(combined_boot_results %>% dplyr::select(orfcs_ac,orfcs_cd, hints_cd),1,prod)
  hie_result <- summarize_calculated_effect(hybrid_indirect_effect1)
  hybrid_effect_set <- append(hybrid_effect_set,list("availability_consumption"=hie_result))
  
  cat("Hybrid effect via food consumption (independently of availability):\n ")
  hybrid_indirect_effect2 <- apply(combined_boot_results %>% dplyr::select(orfcs_ad,hints_cd),1,prod)
  hie_result <- summarize_calculated_effect(hybrid_indirect_effect2)
  hybrid_effect_set <- append(hybrid_effect_set,list("consumption_alone"=hie_result))
  
  hybrid_effect_set_df <- do.call(rbind,hybrid_effect_set)
  hybrid_effect_set_df$outcome<-effect_name
  hybrid_effect_set_df$pathway <- rownames(hybrid_effect_set_df)
  
  hybrid_effect_list<-append(hybrid_effect_list,list(hybrid_effect_set_df))
  
  
  #"The total effect is the sum of the direct and indirect effects"
  # - https://www.annualreviews.org/doi/pdf/10.1146/annurev-publhealth-032315-021402
  #there are three total effects we want to calculate: ORFCS, HINTS, and hybrid
  #For these path models we need to sum up all paths (the different kinds of indirect effects)
  #so for ORFCS this is going to be:
  #orfcs_ab*orfcs_bc*orfcs_cd*orfcs_de
  #orfcs_ab*orfcs_bc*orfcs_ce
  #orfcs_ab*orfcs_bd*orfcs_de
  #orfcs_ab*orfcs_be
  #orfcs_ac*orfcs_cd*orfcs_de
  #orfcs_ac*orfcs_ce
  #orfcs_ad*orfcs_de
  #orfcs_ae
  calculate_path_effect<-function(path_vector){
    return(apply(combined_boot_results[,path_vector],1,prod))
  }
  cat("total effect of the ORFCS model:\n")
  total_effect_orfcs<-(
    calculate_path_effect(paste0("orfcs_",c("ab","bc","cd","de")))+
      calculate_path_effect(paste0("orfcs_",c("ab","bc","ce")))+
      calculate_path_effect(paste0("orfcs_",c("ab","bd","de")))+
      calculate_path_effect(paste0("orfcs_",c("ab","be")))+
      calculate_path_effect(paste0("orfcs_",c("ac","cd","de")))+
      calculate_path_effect(paste0("orfcs_",c("ac","ce")))+
      calculate_path_effect(paste0("orfcs_",c("ad","de")))+
      combined_boot_results$orfcs_ae
  )
  hie_result <- summarize_calculated_effect(total_effect_orfcs)
  hybrid_effect_set <- append(hybrid_effect_set,list("total_effect_orfcs"=hie_result))
  
  cat("total effect of the HINTS model:\n")
  total_effect_hints<-(
    calculate_path_effect(paste0("hints_",c("ab","bc","cd")))+
      calculate_path_effect(paste0("hints_",c("ab","bd")))+
      calculate_path_effect(paste0("hints_",c("ac","cd")))+
      combined_boot_results$hints_ad
  )
  hie_result <- summarize_calculated_effect(total_effect_hints)
  hybrid_effect_set <- append(hybrid_effect_set,list("total_effect_hints"=hie_result))
  
  cat("HINTS proportion mediated:\n")
  hints_prop_mediated<-HINTS_indirect_effect/total_effect_hints
  hie_result <- summarize_calculated_effect(hints_prop_mediated)
  hybrid_effect_set <- append(hybrid_effect_set,list("hints_prop_mediated"=hie_result))
  
  
  cat("total effect of the hybrid model:\n")
  total_effect_hybrid<-(
    calculate_path_effect(c(paste0("orfcs_",c("bc","cd")),paste0("hints_",c("ab","cd"))))+
      #calculate_path_effect(c(paste0("orfcs_",c("ab","bc","ce")),paste0("hints_",c("ab","bc","ce"))))+
      calculate_path_effect(paste0("hints_",c("ab","bc","cd")))+
      calculate_path_effect(c(paste0("hints_",c("ab","bd"))))+
      calculate_path_effect(c(paste0("orfcs_",c("ac","cd")),paste0("hints_",c("cd"))))+
      #calculate_path_effect(c(paste0("orfcs_",c("ac","ce")),paste0("hints_",c("ac","ce"))))+
      calculate_path_effect(c(paste0("hints_",c("ac","cd"))))+
      combined_boot_results$hints_ad
  )
  
  hie_result <- summarize_calculated_effect(total_effect_hybrid)
  hybrid_effect_set <- append(hybrid_effect_set,list("total_effect_hybrid"=hie_result))

  cat("hybrid proportion mediated:\n")
  hints_prop_mediated<-hybrid_main_indirect_effect/total_effect_hybrid
  hie_result <- summarize_calculated_effect(hints_prop_mediated)
  hybrid_effect_set <- append(hybrid_effect_set,list("hints_prop_mediated"=hie_result))
  

  cat("---------\n\n\n")

}

hybrid_effect_df<-do.call(rbind,hybrid_effect_list)

```

```{r, warning=FALSE}
  #orfcs_ac*orfcs_cd*orfcs_de
  #orfcs_ac*orfcs_ce
  #orfcs_ad*orfcs_de
  #orfcs_ae
  calculate_path_effect<-function(path_vector){
    return(apply(combined_boot_results[,path_vector],1,prod))
  }
  cat("total effect of the ORFCS model:\n")
  total_effect_orfcs<-(
    calculate_path_effect(paste0("orfcs_",c("ab","bc","cd","de")))+
      calculate_path_effect(paste0("orfcs_",c("ab","bc","ce")))+
      calculate_path_effect(paste0("orfcs_",c("ab","bd","de")))+
      calculate_path_effect(paste0("orfcs_",c("ab","be")))+
      calculate_path_effect(paste0("orfcs_",c("ac","cd","de")))+
      calculate_path_effect(paste0("orfcs_",c("ac","ce")))+
      calculate_path_effect(paste0("orfcs_",c("ad","de")))+
      combined_boot_results$orfcs_ae
  )
  hie_result <- summarize_calculated_effect(total_effect_orfcs)
  hybrid_effect_set <- append(hybrid_effect_set,list("total_effect_orfcs"=hie_result))
  
  cat("total effect of the HINTS model:\n")
  total_effect_hints<-(
    calculate_path_effect(paste0("hints_",c("ab","bc","cd")))+
      calculate_path_effect(paste0("hints_",c("ab","bd")))+
      calculate_path_effect(paste0("hints_",c("ac","cd")))+
      combined_boot_results$hints_ad
  )
  hie_result <- summarize_calculated_effect(total_effect_hints)
  hybrid_effect_set <- append(hybrid_effect_set,list("total_effect_hints"=hie_result))
  
  cat("HINTS proportion mediated:\n")
  hints_prop_mediated<-HINTS_indirect_effect/total_effect_hints
  hie_result <- summarize_calculated_effect(hints_prop_mediated)
  hybrid_effect_set <- append(hybrid_effect_set,list("hints_prop_mediated"=hie_result))
  
  
  # cat("total effect of the hybrid model:\n")
  # total_effect_hybrid<-(
  #   calculate_path_effect(c(paste0("orfcs_",c("bc","cd")),paste0("hints_",c("ab","cd"))))+
  #     #calculate_path_effect(c(paste0("orfcs_",c("ab","bc","ce")),paste0("hints_",c("ab","bc","ce"))))+
  #     calculate_path_effect(paste0("hints_",c("ab","bc","cd")))+

  #     calculate_path_effect(c(paste0("orfcs_",c("ac","cd")),paste0("hints_",c("cd"))))+
  #     #calculate_path_effect(c(paste0("orfcs_",c("ac","ce")),paste0("hints_",c("ac","ce"))))+

  #     combined_boot_results$hints_ad
  # )

  cat("---------\n\n\n")

}
```

## Notes

On its face, this "hybrid effect" shows that if we assume relationships between (a) household income and health food availability and (b) health food availability and fruit and veggie consumption are the same in the HINTS population as they are in the ORFCS population, then rurality has an indirect effect through health food availability in HINTS, too.

```{r}
#can use this function for all sorts of labels, not just a particular kind
label_rename<-function(label){
  #effect routes
  label[label=="effect_via_fruit_vege_only"]<-"Via fruit and vegetable consumption"
  label[label=="effect_via_inc_only"]<-"Via income only"
  label[label=="availability_consumption"]<-"Via fruit and vegetable availability and consumption"
  label[label=="consumption_alone"]<-"Via fruit and vegetable consumption alone"
  
  #Outcome labels
  label[label=="GeneralHealth_i"] <- "Self-rated health"
  label[label=="MedConditionsAggregate"] <- "Aggregate cardiometabolic health"
  label[label=="MedConditions_HighBP_i"] <- "High blood pressure/hypertension"
  label[label=="EverHadCancer_i"] <- "Ever had cancer"
  #BMI"                    "GeneralHealth_i"        "MedConditionsAggregate" "MedConditions_HighBP_i" "EverHadCancer_i"   
  
  
  #misc
  label <- sapply(
    label,
    function(l){
      if(l=="BMI") return(l)
      return(str_replace_all(l,"_"," ") %>% str_to_sentence)
    }
  )
    
  return(label)
}

format_CI <- function(ci_lower, ci_upper,digits=digits){
  ci_lower_str <- formatB(ci_lower,digits=digits)
  ci_upper_str <- formatB(ci_upper,digits=digits)
  return(paste0("[",ci_lower_str,", ",ci_upper_str,"]"))
}
```

With this analysis I would tend to think we don't need to proceed to use Zipcode Median Household Income. It would tend to make the analysis more complicated, but what are the benefits? Primarily, it seems to be more strongly related to rurality (z=-14 for Zipcode household median income, compared to z=-4 for household income). However, it is not more strongly related to healthy food availability and SES. Finally, it is *less* strongly related to BMI; household income predicts BMI (z=-3.4) but zipcode median income does not (z=0.9). Because BMI is a variable of interest, or at least a proxy thereof, that seems to be the determining factor. If we include Zipcode Median household income, that will complicate the model without obvious benefit.

## Hours worked

Neither study records hours worked, although both record work status (full time/part time/unemployed). These would probably be predictive, but are not of particular interest, and I'm not aware of how we'd interpret this any differently to income, which is already included in the model.

# Pruning/regularization Oregon dataset

We can cut the dataset down, and perhaps observe slightly larger effects, by cutting the dataset down to size. Suitable rules might be:

-   Include all possible pathways to start with

-   Of the beta estimates with p\>0.1 and which are not part of a p\>0.1 pathway, remove the least significant

-   Test for goodness of fit. If it's an improvement, keep variable out and repeat. If it's not an improvement, keep it in and repeat

-   Repeat until there are no variables to take out.

-   

    ```{r}
    oregon_full_model_template=
    "
      #Regressions
      aSES_02_z ~ ab*RuralZIP_i + DEMO_Age_c + DEMO_Age_c_pow2 + Gender3C_Male + Gender3C_Other + RaceC2_Asian + RaceC2_HawaiianOtherPacificIslander + RaceC2_HispanicAnyRace + RaceC2_OtherRaceRaceNotReported
      
      MESA_healthyfoodavailability_z ~ bc*aSES_02_z + ac*RuralZIP_i + DEMO_Age_c + DEMO_Age_c_pow2 + Gender3C_Male + Gender3C_Other + RaceC2_Asian + RaceC2_HawaiianOtherPacificIslander + RaceC2_HispanicAnyRace + RaceC2_OtherRaceRaceNotReported
      
      FFQ_fruit_vegetables_z ~ cd*MESA_healthyfoodavailability_z + bd*aSES_02_z + ad*RuralZIP_i + DEMO_Age_c + DEMO_Age_c_pow2 + Gender3C_Male + Gender3C_Other + RaceC2_Asian + RaceC2_HawaiianOtherPacificIslander + RaceC2_HispanicAnyRace + RaceC2_OtherRaceRaceNotReported
      
      (OUTCOMEVAR) ~ de*FFQ_fruit_vegetables_z + ce*MESA_healthyfoodavailability_z + be*aSES_02_z + ae*RuralZIP_i + DEMO_Age_c + DEMO_Age_c_pow2 + Gender3C_Male + Gender3C_Other + RaceC2_Asian + RaceC2_HawaiianOtherPacificIslander + RaceC2_HispanicAnyRace + RaceC2_OtherRaceRaceNotReported
      
      
      #Defined Parameters:
      indirect_effect := ab*bc*cd*de
      #cut one parameter
      effect_abce :=ab*bc*ce #makes no particular theoretical sense but for regularization rules, I want to observe it
      effect_via_food := ac*cd*de
      effect_via_inc_eating := ab*bd*de
      #cut two parameters
      effect_via_income := ab*be
      effect_ace := ac*ce
      effect_via_eating := ad*de
      #cut all mediators
      direct_effect := ae
    "

    # - Outcome: Physical and health measures. Altogether, we'll repeat the mediation several times, with the following outcomes variables: BMI, self-rated health, aggregated cardiometabolic health, and high blood pressure.

    outcome_measures <- c(
      "BMI"#,
      #"GeneralHealth_i",
      #"MedConditionsAggregate",
      #"MedConditions_HighBP_i",
      #"EverHadCancer_i"#no cancer for now, doesn't seem very important.
      )
    ```

    ```{r}
      #cut two parameters
      effect_via_income := ab*be
      #effect_ace := ac*ce
      effect_via_eating := ad*de
      #cut all mediators
      direct_effect := ae
    "
    ```


The next pruning again looks like an improvement on BIC and mabye on AIC. So we can proceed to a third pruning. Direct effect of rurality on eating, `ad`, isn't significant, and neither is the path that uses it. So we can eliminate it and try again.

## Third pruning

At least according to BIC, this model is a better fit. All remaining path variables are significant, and remaining paths are either significant or marginally significant, so that's as far as it goes.

Knowing all of this, perhaps it's not a big deal for the HINTS dataset that it doesn't have separate variables for consumption and availability. they seem quite related.

All modeled variables are now significant at least at the p\>0.1 level, and in fact, they're all significant at the p\<0.01 level, so we are done pruning.
